comments:
Finance 412 provides students with an analytic framework for addressing how a corporation finances its activities and what investments it should make. Key aspects are the net-present-value approach to valuation and a portfolio approach to understanding risk. Topics include present-value techniques, valuation, the relationship between risk and return, capital market efficiency, the choice between equity and debt financing, and dividend policy. This course utilizes basic algebra; prospective participants who need to refresh their skills in this area can contact a WPWP representative for assistance before enrolling. ACCT 411 or a familiarity with financial accounting is recommended.

Students were sometimes overwhelmed by the amount of work in the course, but found that the class materials were extremely valuable. Almost all students found that they learned a lot from the course and very much so enjoyed it. One student noted that “this course was very interesting and a good entry into financial thinking.”

Students thoroughly praised Professor La May’s teaching by saying he was “clear” and “well-organized.” Students generally found him very accessible and stated that he connected the coursework and class discussions well. 

Students were slightly overwhelmed by the workload and found that they recommended taking several accounting classes before taking this course.
